rows.title: Good day! This is a reminder that the first MaPa Chat module will start [SET TIME] later. I'm excited to start the program with you! We'll start building a Happy Home with a simple yet effective tip: doing One-on-One Time. You will see what it can do for your family! Let's meet!

rows.title: Hello! Thank you for attending our session! Remember, our main activity this week is One-on-One Time with your child. Even just 5 minutes can go a long way! You can do this!

title.eng: Hello! Thank you for attending our session! Remember, our main activity this week is One-on-One Time with your child. Even just 5 minutes can go a long way! You can do this!

rows.title: Hi! How is your practice of the homework assignment going? I understand that you may have some challenges with this module. Feel free to text me if you have any questions.Thank you!

title.eng: Hi! How is your practice of the homework assignment going? I understand that you may have some challenges with this module. Feel free to text me if you have any questions.Thank you!

rows.title: Review the chat

text.eng:
1️⃣ Review the messages from the previous module. Take note of parents who may need additional support.

2️⃣ Review the feedback from the previous module. Select a success that can be linked to the foundations in the live chat.

3️⃣ Choose a challenge that the group can work together to solve in the live chat.

2: Discussion: Burial Work
3: Sharing Success

rows.title: Building Blocks of Module 1: One-on-one time

title.eng: Building Blocks of Module 1: One-on-one time

text.eng:
1️⃣ DAY- Try to do this every day.
Set aside 5 minutes (or more!) each day for One-on-One Time with your child.

2️⃣ GAME- Let them choose what to do.
Tell your child that you have time for One-on-One Time with them, and they can choose what they want to do or what they want to talk about. They may be hesitant at first, but eventually they will look forward to spending time with you!

3️⃣ ATTENTION- Give your child your full attention.
Turn off the TV and put away the cell phone. Look at your child. Nod or say “I see” to show that you are paying full attention. Show interest in his story and accept what he says without judgment.

rows.title: Building Blocks of Module 2: Talking about feelings

title.eng: Building Blocks of Module 2: Talking about feelings

text.eng:
1️⃣ BREATHE  -  Breathe  before  you  start  to  calm  yourself  down. 
2️⃣ SHARE  -  Share  your  feelings. 
3️⃣ LISTEN  -  Listen  to  your  child  or  teenager. 
4️⃣ PAINFUL  -  Concerned  for  them. 
5️⃣ FIND  -  Find  the  positive  `

rows.text:

2️⃣ SHARE  -  Share  your  feelings. 
3️⃣ LISTEN  -  Listen  to  your  child  or  teenager. 
4️⃣ PAINFUL  -  Concerned  for  them. 
5️⃣ FIND  -  Find  the  positive  `

rows.title: Possible answers from parents

text.eng:
Grandma  noticed  Jun-Jun's  feelings  by  saying,  ""I  see."" that  you  are  sad"". •

Use  words  to  describe  emotions.  

Repeated  what  Jun-Jun  said,  “This  is  not  easy”. 
The  child  was  comforted. 

Shares  own  feelings  about  the  situation  by  saying “I'm  happy  to  be  with  you  today,  Jun-Jun”. 

Looked  for  a  solution.

rows.text:
Grandma  noticed  Jun-Jun's  feelings  by  saying,  ""I  see."" that  you  are  sad"". •

Use  words  to  describe  emotions.  

Repeated  what  Jun-Jun  said,  “This  is  not  easy”. 
The  child  was  comforted. 

Shares  own  feelings  about  the  situation  by  saying “I'm  happy  to  be  with  you  today,  Jun-Jun”. 

Looked  for  a  solution.

rows.title: Possible answers from parents

text.eng:
The parent remains calm.

The parent accepts the emotion (fear) – even if it is negative.

The parent explains his feelings.

The parent notices that their child is anxious and tries to calm them down

He explained it by saying, “It’s normal to feel this way.”

The parent showed sympathy and support using words to

Let the teenager know that he is there for them.

The parent pays attention to how their child feels
teenager

The parent and the teenager worked together to find a solution – which
doesn't mean there is an answer to everything!

rows.title: Possible answers from parents

text.eng:
Teaches children to share their feelings.

Helps the child connect emotions with actions and body
language.

The child learns that all emotions are acceptable.

Parents can see and learn about their child's feelings
child.

Teaches children to recognize other people's emotions.

Gives the child the opportunity to change their behavior.

rows.title: Before your session, discuss with your co-facilitator

title.eng: Before your session, discuss with your co-facilitator

text.eng:
1. Read the module for the session carefully and make sure you are clear about the objectives for your discussion.

2. Write down notes that will help you conduct the session.

3. It may be helpful to write down different ways of asking questions to participants. T

4. You can also practice conducting or discussing some parts of the session with your co-facilitator!

5. Decide who among you and the co-facilitator will lead the activities and who will provide support.

6. Review each participant's documents to see their progress in the program and to note who needs additional support. 

7. Divide the time according to the needs of the group. 

8. Arrive early to prepare the space to be used.

rows.text:
1. Read the module for the session carefully and make sure you are clear about the objectives for your discussion.

2. Write down notes that will help you conduct the session.

3. It may be helpful to write down different ways of asking questions to participants. T

4. You can also practice conducting or discussing some parts of the session with your co-facilitator!

5. Decide who among you and the co-facilitator will lead the activities and who will provide support.

6. Review each participant's documents to see their progress in the program and to note who needs additional support. 

7. Divide the time according to the needs of the group. 

8. Arrive early to prepare the space to be used.

rows.title: Materials required for the session

text.eng:
**The materials listed should be sufficient for 15 participants**

Pencils, bond paper, ballpoint pen, pentel pen, scotch tape, name tags

Comic posters and handouts


Snack for the break

**Other materials are for the whole group**

Flipchart for participants' ideas

Video camera if you will be recording the session

Some things that MaPa Staff will determine are:

Reimbursement for transportation, attendance list, and other forms required by MaPa

Flashcards (6 pieces for parents) or Projector + Section 2.1
